results.title: Old enough but not ready: early recognition of learning disabilities
results.creator_credit: Barrie Angus McLean and Robert Anderson Associates
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Learning Series”.
Derek behaves as if he had difficulty uttering words; Eugene is unable to follow verbal instructions such as “left”, “first, “after”; Mark has yet to use his hands as though the fingers are ten distinct elements. Children of six and seven who are bright and cheerful but for various reasons are not yet able to cope with the demands made in a Grade One classroom. Dr. Sam Rabinovitch explains the advantage of early recognition of learning disabilities in children. Shows the learning and teaching difficulties of these children.

results.title: I'm not too famous at it: a definition of learning disabilities
results.creator_credit: Robert Anderson, Barrie Angus McLean and Canadian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Learning Series”.
The title was named by Robert, a bright nine year old, who lacks eye-hand coordination, has difficulty appreciating the characteristics of shapes and forms, has language difficulties of various kinds, who has poor gross motor coordination and other problems. While defining and describing these learning deficits indirectly shows somthing of the process of remediation.

results.title: Start to Read
results.creator_credit: Tony Wise, Jacky Moini, Video Collection and Thames Television
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Learn with Sooty”.
This video explains the importance of knowing how to read, with many examples and exercises which show this to be true. The video will help young children learn at their own individual pace in a way that is both meaningful and enjoyable.

results.title: Thaumatropes
results.brief_description: A thaumatrope is an optical toy that binds a disc to lengths of string. Illustrated on each side of the disc are distinct images that become one when you pull the string and the thaumatrope spins.

constellations_primary.name: There's always a lighthouse
constellations_primary.description: The thaumatrope was an early optical illusion device popular in the Victorian era and was important to the development of the moving image.

results.description: How do you cage a bird? With a thaumatrope, an optical toy that binds a disc to lengths of string. Illustrated on each side of the disc are distinct images that become one when you pull the string and the thaumatrope spins. The first known thaumatrope was invented by John Ayrton Paris in 1824, when he used it to demonstrate his theory of ‘persistence of vision’ to London’s Royal College of Physicians.
description_for_label: How do you cage a bird? With a thaumatrope, an optical toy that binds a disc to lengths of string. Illustrated on each side of the disc are distinct images that become one when you pull the string and the thaumatrope spins. The first known thaumatrope was invented by John Ayrton Paris in 1824, when he used it to demonstrate his theory of ‘persistence of vision’ to London’s Royal College of Physicians.

results.title: Mao: organised chaos
results.creator_credit: Don Thompson, Sam Summerlin, Pat Ferns, New York Times Productions and Nielsen-Ferns
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Leaders of the twentieth century: portraits of power”.
Second in a two part film on Mao Tse-tung. Looks at Mao and his regime from the proclamation of the People’s Republic of China on 1st October 1949, to his death in 1976. Follows the cultural revolution; the elimination of Mao’s enemies; Mao’s visit to Moscow; the Korean War; Chiang’s regime; and Nixon’s visit to China. Narrated by Henry Fonda. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Mao: long march to power
results.creator_credit: Don Thompson, Sam Summerlin, Pat Ferns, New York Times Productions and Nielsen-Ferns
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Leaders of the twentieth century: portraits of power”.
First in a two part film on Mao Tse-tung. His beginnings as a peasant farmer through to his rise to power in the 1949 revolution are highlighted in this film. Attention is also given to Sun Yat Sen’s nationalists: Chiang Kai-shek and Mao’s Communist Party of 1921. Narrated by Henry Fonda. Suitable for upper secondary levels.

results.title: Kip and David. Episode 08
results.creator_credit: Corinne Cantrill, Arthur Cantrill and Firebird Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “Kip and David”.
It is David’s birthday and Kip is the first to greet him, playing ‘Happy Birthday’ on his pipes. David is given a small microscope and some boxes of prepared slides. They look at some of these and then find things in the garden to inspect under the microscope. The postman brings another parcel, which contains an irrepressible Jack-in-the-Box. Music by Nancy Tow. Narrated by Roy Dunlop.

results.title: Dodging with Chuck O'Connell
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Lacrosse - the Fastest Game on Two Feet”.
An instructional film for student players, demonstrating the technique of dodging in lacrosse. With coach Chuck O’Donnell.
